Ibuprofen blocks the kidney-protective and BP-lowering effects of lisinopril; can cause acute kidney injury.
Thyroid hormone increases the breakdown of clotting factors, significantly boosting warfarin's effect and bleeding risk.
Rosuvastatin can enhance the anticoagulant effect of warfarin, requiring more frequent blood tests (INR) to avoid bleeding.
zyban raises sertraline levels (Kinetic) and both drugs lower the seizure threshold (Dynamic).
Both lower blood sugar via different pathways; taking them together significantly increases the risk of hypoglycemia
Like ibuprofen, aspirin can reduce the effectiveness of lisinopril and potentially strain the kidneys.
A common therapeutic pairing, but the additive effect on the GI tract (nausea/diarrhea) can be difficult to tolerate initially.
Both target the same blood pressure system; using them together causes high potassium and severe kidney stress.
Omeprazole reduces stomach acid; without enough acid, the thyroid pill cannot dissolve or absorb into the body correctly.
Both slow the heart or relax vessels; combined they can cause an excessively slow heart rate or very low blood pressure.
